Problem:
Consider a system of linear equations modeled by \( Ax = b \), where A is a non-singular matrix. An operator \( T \) defined by \( T(x) = Ux \) (where \( U \) is a diagonal matrix with positive entries) is applied, modifying the vector \( x \) in the space.

If at a certain point \( t_1 \), an intervention via a scaling matrix \( V \) (another diagonal matrix with positive entries) is applied to the system, will the final state \( x(T) \) be representative only of the initial application \( T \) and not \( V \)?
Explanation: The intervention with scaling matrix \( V \) further alters the state of the system. The resultant state at time \( T \) depends on both the initial transformation by \( U \) and the later application of \( V \), thus reflecting the effects of both.
